description.narrative:
Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS) is one of the largest international household survey programmes worldwide. It is designed to collect estimates of key indicators that are used to assess the situation on households and especially of children and women.
Government of Georgia decided to participate in the sixth round of MICS with support of UNICEF to collect comprehensive, nationally and regionally representative data for key indicators of the situation of households, especially children and women, and thus to strengthen its capacities for evidence-based strategic policymaking towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG).
The MICS field survey will be conducted during September - December, 2018, followed by a period of data analysis up until the release of the survey results in March 2019. After the release of the data, the project is planning to conduct a series of trainings and workshops for journalists during 2019, covering dataintepretation and public awareness of the survey results.

Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS) är en av världens största hushållsundersökningar. Den är utformad för att samla uppskattningar av nyckelindikatorer som behövs för att bedöma hushållens situation och särskilt för barn och kvinnor.
Den georgiska regeringen har beslutat att delta i den sjätte omgången av MICS med stöd av UNICEF för att samla omfattande, nationellt och regionalt representativa data för nyckelindikatorer för hushållens situation, med särskilt fokus på barn och kvinnor, och på så vis stärka sin kapacitet att genomföra evidensbaserad strategisk policyutveckling för att uppnå de Globala målen (SDGs).
MICS hushållsundersökninge kommer att genomföras under september - december 2018, följt av en period för dataanalysering fram till det att resultaten realiseras i mars 2019. Projektet planerar även att genomföra en rad utbildningar och workkshops för journalister under 2019, som kommer att inkludera datainterpretering och medvetandesarbete kring resultaten av MICS.

The objective of the MICS 6 will be effectively to address existing data gaps and provide the Government of Georgia and its development partners with accurate, nationally and regionally representative estimates of indicators on the situation of households, especially children and women, in Georgia. Consequently, the Government of Georgia will be better equipped for evidence-based strategic policymaking towards achieving the SDGs, while the development partners will be better prepared to support this process through appropriate technical assistance. The MICS 6 will also result in increased capacities of GeoStat to carry out big household surveys and using the new Computer-Assisted Personal Interviewing (CAPI) technology.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: As a result of MIC6 findings and follow up communication with different interested parties the following results have been achieved: • The Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport started addressing the lack of preschool services in rural areas through opening preschool classrooms in primary school facilities in villages countrywide. • The Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport, acknowledging the existing inequities in general education, conducted an evidence-based in-depth analysis of education data which is being used to develop a corresponding action plan. • The Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport, responded to the alarming data on out-of-school children and, through its social workforce at the Office of Resource Officers of Education Institution, started to reach out to children deprived of the right to education and address their issues individually. In addition, the Ministry strengthened its “Second Chance Education” programme for a more targeted approach to reduce the number of out-of-school children. • The Ministry of Internally Displaced Persons from the Occupied Territories, Labor, Health and Social Affairs decided to revise the bylaws for the enforcement of Georgia’s Law on Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes to encourage and promote breastfeeding, and the data triggered prioritization of overweight prevention on the policy agenda and the development of a regulatory framework for school nutrition in Georgia. • To respond to the water quality challenges, the Ministry of Regional Development and Infrastructure revised the water infrastructure programme to prioritize the regions most affected by E-coli contamination and is in the process of establishing a partnership of key stakeholders to plan the actions for improving water quality. • Finally, the Parliament of Georgia adopted the Code on the Rights of the Child, which fully prohibits corporal punishment in any setting and encourages development of positive parenting programmes at the municipal level to support parents in bringing up their children. • To respond to the data derived from MICS on elevated blood levels amongst 41 per cent of 2-7 year-old children in Georgia, a partnership between UNICEF and the Government of Georgia was launched. The Government of Georgia developed a response action plan which includes further research into the sources of lead exposure, as well as free of charge medical support, including medicines, for children with elevated blood lead levels and their family members. UNICEF is supporting the Government with the equipment required to undertake Phase II of the MICS BLL module i.e. the study of lead exposure sources and pathways.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
